title: Five-year mortgage at 3.49pc - for borrowers with just 10pc deposit
text:
34.40 -1.25 
Some lenders are continuing to cut rates as they target new borrowers - but are the deals all they seem? 
HSBC is offering a five-year fixed mortgage priced at 3.49pc for borrowers with a 10c deposit. 
The loan comes with a £999 upfront fee and applicants' borrowing is limited to £400,000. If you are an HSBC Advance or Premier (NasdaqGS: PINC - news ) account holder you could qualify for a reduced fee. 
Moneyfacts.co.uk, the mortgage and savings rates analyst, has awarded the product its highest rating “outstanding” because of its very low rate coupled with an unusually low deposit requirement. 
But how does it stack up against other similar deals on the market? 
Mortgage calculators 
- How much can I borrow? 
- Monthly cost of your repayments 
= Verdict: = 
There’s no denying that the rate, and crucially the fee, are competitive. 
Overall, fixed rates have started creeping up in recent weeks ahead of a widely anticipated interest rate rise, but deals for borrowers with a small deposit have been largely unaffected. 
There are a few rates on the market that are slightly lower than HSBC's offering, including Norwich and Peterborough and First Direct’s 3.47pc deals. But these come with higher fees: £1,295 and £1,450 respectively. 
Peter Gettins, of mortgage broker London and Country, said West Bromwich Building Society’s new five-year fix could beat HSBC's deal for some borrowers, particularly those who want a small loan. 
“It’s a higher rate of 3.69pc but with a small £199 fee, free valuation and £500 cashback, it is very competitive. This is particularly true for loans worth up to about £200,000 or so. Beyond this amount the higher rate will start to outweigh the small fee. 
“So I wouldn’t say the HSBC deal is setting a new standard, but with a 10pc deposit it’s about as good as you’ll get.”
